measured_by: stay/shift response patterns (win-stay, win-shift, lose-stay, lose-shift) in the Matching Pennies task
justification: The authors state that they “measure behavioural consistency when participants intentionally play a game” and repeatedly analyse how consistently participants deploy win-stay, win-shift, lose-stay and lose-shift behaviours across 540 rounds of the Matching Pennies game.

measured_by: correlation between win rate and win-stay / lose-shift indices
justification: Results sections report that “both the degree of win-stay (r = .708) and lose-shift (r = .423) positively correlated with win rate,” treating these correlations as the quantitative indicator of how strongly outcomes are linked to subsequent actions.

measured_by: mismatch between expected and observed outcomes created by win-maximization versus loss-maximization instructions
justification: In the Discussion the authors explain that disruption arises from “the error generated between the expected outcome of winning and the observed outcome of losing,” indicating that the experimentally induced match or mismatch of expected versus actual outcomes serves as their operational measure of unsigned prediction error.
